channel.title: Robocup on UCOSP
channel.description: Recent content in Robocup on UCOSP

item.title: screencast
item.description: Our screencast is posted here Links to a few other videos we’ve made: Human controls Another demo Playing a game against last term’s team

item.title: One Positive, One Negative
item.description: Positive: Finally, I can experience working on a real, fully distributed team. Also, I learn a lot of technical stuff from this course. From programming in python to machine learning algorithms. I am also grateful to learn from my colleagues as this is more practical than learning from textbooks. Negative: I couldn’t contribute to the team as much as I want to. There are various reasons for this but most notably is due to the complexity and difficulty of the project.

item.title: Robocup Status Update
item.description: For the most part we are all trying to wrap things up. Here’s how we plan to divide the final work load. Yulia + Ioana: Look into fixing coordinate system. Chani: Will put together a skeleton of the document. Patrik: Will write up an overview of the source code by Tuesday. Alex: Plans to finish his passing improvements and contribute a write up of why we choose the python code.

item.title: Robocup Meeting
item.description: We had our weekly meeting yesterday (Nov 29th ’09). The minutes and transcript are available here (http://chani.ca/robocup/minutes/nov29.txt). Patrik

item.title: Thoughts on RoboCup
item.description: I worked on RoboCup and I have to say it didn’t turn out to be what I expected in the beginning. But I really enjoyed it despite the problems we had (just like any other team this term). There isn’t a whole lot of bad things I can say about the csc494 experience. We pretty much lost that month before the Code Sprint because we couldn’t get an access to the repository.

item.title: Status updates for Robocup
item.description: We had our meeting on Sunday, November 22. Here is what the team had been up to: Alex – worked on passing, now it takes into account players from the opposit team – it is hard to make 100% accurate passing because of the noise added to the measurements Next task: – work on interception as it is related to passing Chani – fixed code so that now players are using data from the current tick

item.title: Thoughts
item.description: Being a part of the Robocup UCOSP project has been an interesting experience. First, I’ll discusses some of the issues with this project. It’s not actually an open source project, and it’s not really under development by anyone other then my group members. This is an issue because we didn’t really get to experience that side of an open source project (ie. being part of a larger picture and lending a hand).

item.title: thumbs up, thumbs down
item.description: the good: Working with a good team. We’ve all had those projects where half the team is asleep or incapable of communicating or just doesn’t do their work. This was one of those rare group projects where I got to be in a group of students who *wanted* to be there. it’s something I’m more used to in the free software world but not in school. the bad: The chaos. Having our team drop to 5 people threw off a lot of the plans we’d made at the sprint.

item.title: Postmortem
item.description: ThumbUp: Having meetings every week and posting status reports helped keep us on track. ThumbDown: I think it would be good to have more variety in projects, in particular some that are less development-oriented and involve more research

item.title: Robocup status update
item.description: alex: -has been trying to improve passing by having the kicker shout out where the ball is going, but the other players don’t always hear it -will try other ways to improve passing chani: -implemented ball and player decay -found out that the code for updating object positions was never being called and fixed that -is working on vision optimization -improved the debug viewer a bit more -may also experiment with changing minimum-confidence values

item.title: Robocup meeting
item.description: Minutes for Robocup’s Nov. 15th meeting

item.title: Robocup meeting
item.description: The minutes from this week’s Robocup meeting can be found here

item.title: Robocup Status Updates
item.description: Alex: Status: – submitted a patch to the robocup_dt branch that makes server parameters no longer hardcoded but instead they can be read from the server messages Tasks for this week: – finish up work on server parameters – work on passing Roadblocks: -none Chani: Status: – was away at a conference – committed FindBall action Tasks for this week: – implement compensating for ball decay today – work on vision timing optimzation.

item.title: Robocup Status Updates for week of Nov 2nd
item.description: Ioana Status: – did some reading on DT – wrote a function that computes the last time a slice was seen (for neck rotation) Next steps: – With Yulia, looking at the solution to body_angle bug Roadblock: None Alex Status: – Looking at ways to improve passing Next steps: – Reading server parameters at the beginning of the game instead of hardcoding them. – Improving passing Roadblock: None Yulia Status:

item.title: Robocup Meeting Minutes November 1st
item.description: Available on: http://www.sfu.ca/~ann5/ucosp/meeting-minutes-nov1st.txt

item.title: Robocup Marking Scheme Meeting
item.description: We had an extra meeting on Thursday October the 29th to finalize the marking scheme. The results of the meeting can be found in the blog, the minutes can be found here. Also note that most of our minutes have now been uploaded to one location at http://chani.ccdevnet.org/robocup/minutes/. Patrik

item.title: Grading Scheme for RoboCup
item.description: Team Grade: 40% ** Performance of soccer team – 10%** Fails to beat original team – 0/10 Wins occasionally – 4⁄10 Consistently wins by narrow margin – 8⁄10 Consistently wins by large margin – 10⁄10 ** Report – 10%** Written report explaining everything that was accomplished, remaining problems, TODO for people who might be working with our code. Mark should reflect completeness, justifications and clarity of writing. Documentation – 10%

item.title: Robocup Meeting Minutes Oct 25th
item.description: Available on: http://www.sfu.ca/~ann5/ucosp/meeting-minutes-oct25th.txt

item.title: My Tools of the Trade
item.description: Here’s a list of tools I cast essential for carrying out my day-to-day business or I find otherwise useful. Hardware (in no particular order)** ** My primary workstation is a HP Pavillion Slimline, a pretty much standard, off-the-shelf PC on which I installed Ubuntu Linux. The hardware works reasonable well under Linux, but at some point I wish hardware vendors would just offer some models which work seamlessly with any major OS.

item.title: Robocup Status Update
item.description: Alex Status: – Tried to tweak to Java client to produce data file for Decision Tree. However, it was cancelled since we might not need it due to Yulia’s work to parse server log file. – Training a goalie with the human controller to produce a convincing data file. Next tasks: – Testing Yulia’s log parser. – Finding the right parameters to build Decision Tree. Roadblocks: – It is very difficult to get a high-quality of training data for building a good Decision Tree.

item.title: Robocup Status Report for Oct 14, 2009
item.description: Ioana Status: Working on the debug GUI Next tasks: When the ball is lost during dribbling, look towards where it was instead of spinning wildly. Roadblocks: None Chani: Status: Have been busy with other course assignments Next Tasks: Make multi-tick actions possible instead of always choosing an action from scratch every tick (which should make Ioana’s next task easier too). Roadblocks:

item.title: Meeting Minutes Robocup Oct 3rd, 2009

item.title: RoboCup — Day 2
item.description: The RoboCup team achieved the following during day two of the code sprint weekend: Decided on 7 tasks we plan to implement by the end of the term Began working on debugging and testing techniques Dealt with more technical issues

item.title: Day 1 From Everyone Else
item.description:
The Basie team posted their first-day report on their blog. No word yet from Ingres or MarkUs, but we’re hopeful 🙂 And just to prove we’re all here: Basie Eclipse4Edu
ElmCity
Ingres
MarkUs
Robocup
Thunderbird
**_WikiDev _**

item.title: Robocup: Day 1
item.description: The Robocup team had their first in-person meeting yesterday. For the first couple of hours, we played around with some of the clients developed by the students who worked on this project over the summer. Then, we had a meeting with Steve Engles, where we decided on the language an code base we want to use. We decided to go with one of the Python clients, because the Java one was using a lot of third-party code and we felt that we wouldn’t be able to improve on it from the beginning, and the other Python client was too basic.

item.title: Status Updates
item.description: Here are the latest progress reports from the teams (with Ingres, Thunderbird, and WikiDev still to come): Basie * Build a toy application in Django and check it into the Subversion repository to prove that they have started learning the framework. Get Basie running on their development machine and send us a URL so that we can check it. Fix some of our broken test fixtures (long story) and put their changes up for code review.

item.title: Second Robocup meeting.
item.description: The Robocup team had their second meeting earlier this week. Minutes can be found here.

item.title: Robocup team's first meeting
item.description: The robocup team had their first meeting sept 10th. Minutes are here.

item.title: Ioana Ivan
item.description: Hi, I’m Ioana Ivan and I’ll be working on the RoboCup project. I’m in my forth year at UofT, doing a specialist in bioinformatics and computational biology, but I’m thinking about staying for an extra year and switching into AI. I’d like to go to graduate school after I graduate. Last year, I did an internship at Red Hat, working on the IcedTea/Openjdk team. I’ve previously worked on a second year research project in bioinformatics at UofT, and a research project on medical imaging at Oxford.

item.title: Brent Mombourquette
item.description: Hi, I’m Brent Mombourquette. I’m in my third year studying computer science at University of Toronto. I’m aiming for a specialist in Artificial Intelligence, although so far I haven’t taken any AI related courses. During this fall I’ll be working on the RoboCup Soccer project. I spent this past summer working with Professor Steve Easterbrook, developing a Firefox plug-in to aid climate scientists in researching. It was a great experience, although I was working by myself.

item.title: Chani Armitage
item.description: Hi, I’m Chani Armitage. I’m studying comp sci at Simon Fraser University, and previously studied at BCIT. I work on the KDE project in my free time. I’ve done three Google Summer of Code projects with them now (it’s awesome, you should apply next spring). This fall I’ll be working on the Robocup project. My first programming experience was for an Artificial Life game (Creatures 3), so I’m looking forward to doing some AI programming.

item.title: Alex Nico Napitupulu
item.description: Hi everyone, my name is Alex Nico Napitupulu and I go to SFU studying computing science. This term, I’ll be working on RoboCup project. I have done eight-month coop term at RIM, Mississauga and I am pretty excited to go back to the fabulous city of Toronto. I also did my coop terms at SAP Business Objects Division, where we developed a reporting software, namely Crystal Reports.

item.title: Enrolment Is Now Closed
item.description: With the acceptance of two students from the Université de Sherbrooke, enrolment is now closed for the Fall 2009 term. Our teams stand like this: Alberta Carleton Laval MSU MUN SFU Sherbrooke UBC UT UTM UTS UVI UVic Waterloo Total Basie 1 1 2 2 1 7 Eclipse4Edu 1 1 2 1 5 ElmCity 2 2 1 5 Ingres 2 2 3 7 MarkUs 3 2 1 2 8 RoboCup 2 3 1 6 Thunderbird 1 1 1 2 5 WikiDev 2 2 2 6 Total 3 1 3 5 1 6 2 1 11 2 1 5 2 6 49 Groups will be having their first team meetings online this week, and will start arriving in Toronto for the code sprint in two and a half weeks.

item.title: Patrik Gornicz
item.description: Hello everyone. I’m Patrik Gornicz who will be working on the RoboCup project. I am a third year student at the University of Waterloo in their Computer Science program. I have enjoyed their coop program by tutoring CS for two terms. My other two coop terms have been spent programming the MediaGo application for Sony Creative Software. As a hobby I’ve been developing a personal C++ library that is currently being used by a simple 2D physics simulator.

item.title: Yulia Kotseruba
item.description: Hi, my name is Yulia Kotseruba and I’m going to be working on RoboCup project this term. I’m fairly new to Computer Science. Having completed a BA in Philosophy and Religious Studies 3 years ago I got into Specialist program in Artificial Intelligence at University of Toronto. Currently I’m in my final fourth year. This summer I got an amazing opportunity to work on volumetric projection system called Lighttwist as part of Google Summer of Code.
